question.text: A human male is heterozygous for autosomal genes 'A' and 'B' present on two different chromosomes, and also has hemophilic gene h. What proportion of his sperms will have abh genes?

solution.text: Haemophilic gene h is present on X chromosome. The probability of his sperms having X chromosome or h gene is <math><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac></math> . He is heterozygous Aa. The probability of his sperms having a is <math><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac></math> . Similarly the probability of his sperms having b is <math><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac></math> . Thus, the probability of his sperms having a, b and h gene is <math><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>8</mn></mrow></mfrac></math>
